Skip to the end for a TL;DR or keep reading.

A friend and I decided to pick this game up, both of us have high-end PCs well above the recommended requirements and we live across the street from eachother so our network latency is under 5ms.

This is what I experienced so far:
I tried hosting since I'm usually the better host between us, I could not see his characters but he could see mine.
Enemies automatically hit me the instant they start an attack towards me, not when the attack actually hits. Yes, this included ranged attacks.
Certain quests would not show progress or complete.
Friend tried breaching a door while I kicked it down, his character froze in place.
Our party wiped once, we reload from a save and the game no longer registered input from my controller or keyboard/mouse, luckily I was able to Alt-F4 out of the game to restart it.
My friend experienced several moments where the game would completely freeze for him for extended periods of time, personally my game crashed a few times.
It is apparently possible to drop your loot for others to pick up, it just takes a few tries since the item returns to their inventory when you pick it up and sometimes it'll successfully dupe the item.

Further, I find the game's options to be lacking.
No settings for sensitivity (Aiming mode is extremely sensitive) or camera speed (It turns very slow with a controller).
No rebind options for controllers.
Keyboard controls list axis inputs when rebinding.
HUD lists hotkeys for different input devices (Playstation lists Xbox buttons or keyboard buttons at seemingly random throughout the game).
There is no confirmation dialogue for several important in-game menu options and a misclick can easily result in undesired actions.

Another extremely annoying thing is that regardless of your equipped weapon the aiming reticle is always 5m away from your character even though every weapon has a much longer range than that, even trying to snipe with a sniper rifle (which has a listed range of at least 35m) is difficult since you can't reliably aim at distant targets. Trying to hit distant targets is sometimes impossible anyways since the camera loves to go at a complete top-down angle at times which limits your vision greatly.

Other than that the game lacks another very important feature, the ability to easily create and customize new characters for joining co-op, it really defeats the purpose of going co-op if you can't customize your crew when joining to ensure that your team still retains a versatile setup.

TL;DR: If you're buying this game for the co-op gameplay, DON'T.
If you want it for the single player, you're probably better off playing the first game, at least until they actually finish developing this game, which they clearly haven't despite claiming to be officially released.

Early Access Review

First and Foremost, the game is in Early Release Alpha.  But TL;DR for those of you who have already played the Original Breach and Clear and enjoyed it: get this game.  It's BnC, but with zombies.  I mean, really -- that is pretty awesome.

Graphics:  Nothing ground breaking, but given that the original Breach and Clear was meant for portable devices, that isn't a big surprise.  It still looks great for what it is, and the UI is very serviceable.  The visuals certainly add to the mood, and remind me of certain areas of the urban areas of old school Resident Evil games, which is high praise in my opinion.

Audio:  Music is nice and moody, and adds to the atmosphere nicely.  The audio shifts when entering into tactical mode, which is a nice touch in accenting the feel from live-action to turn-based.  When the music shifts, it gives a feeling of 'alright, lets do this'.  Sound effects are pretty satisfying too, gunfire sounds hefty, explosions are, well, explosive.  Very solid.

Gameplay:  It's Breach and Clear, man.  Very entertaining tactical action, especially given the circumstances.  I can't say I've ever thought about approaching a zombie apocalypse with military tactics at my finger tips, but it works really well.  In fact, having four well-armed militants at your disposal might seem unfair at first, but not all zombies are created equal, and you'll be surprise how quickly you can get overrun by either sheer numbers.  Using your soldier's abilities (like grenades, mines, tagging enemies, and provoking the horde) goes a long way to keeping your head above water.  Loot crates spread through out the stages encourage exploration, and finding ammo and medical crates when you are low really makes mowing through that horde worth the trouble.  Over all, very engaging game play.

Gripes:  Well, it IS alpha, so I'll try to be easy on it.  Complete lack of tutorial is a bit of a pain, and there is not much in the way of VO, save for when you select your squad mates.  There are bugs, of course.  Getting behind cover can be a pain in the ♥♥♥, as the game doesn't like to give you that shield icon when it damn well should.  Also, the squad AI needs some touching up.  Sometimes, after setting up, they would shoot enemies in the very back, while three are about to eat their face.  And when you are controlling a solo-guy live-action style, sometimes the squad follows you, and sometimes they don't.  And the crates!  Several times I had the item pop out and go right into a car, making it impossible to grab.  And there are a few more things, sure, but again, this is Alpha.  Most of these problems are minor, and don't stop the game from being great.  Just in need of a bit of polish -- but hey!  Alpha is Alpha.  Overall, very solid, and I can't wait to see how much better it gets.

PS:  Will update as I plow through the game.  XD

reviewText:
Breach & Clear: Deadline most certainly does not reinvent the wheel, but is it interesting and engaging enough to hold its own against the multitude of zombie games on market? In a word, no. At its core, the game is essentially a zombie ARPG with a bland strategy component. Every element incorporated in Deadline is stuff we have all seen before. Of course, all games have borrowed ideas from each other since the beginning, but those who choose to implement these ideas try to improve upon it or at least make it their own. Deadline, on the other hand, barely comes to par with what is released today. Just imagine the ideas of action, strategy and role-playing boiled down to its fundamental gameplay components.

Let us begin with the basic action of the game. The killing of zombies is not even interesting. Six hours played at the time of this review and the types of zombies I have encountered are as follows: zombies that walk, zombies that walk faster, and crawling zombies with more health. For a game that has a strategy feature built in, you would think they would introduce multiple zombie types early. One would agree that having many zombie types would assist in creating a strategic environment; an environment where I would need to carefully plan my actions. At the moment, you roam an open world with loot crates and the occasional zombie encounter. Once an encounter starts, you are brought to the command menu, where you able to issue commands to your four individual squad mates. The options available are essentially move, shoot, use abilities and items. I immediately exit this feature, hold both my mouse buttons down and kill the zombies in my way. After six hours, this can get a little repetitive.

Seems like a great time to talk about strategy. There is none. Simply aim at the zombies and shoot them. Sure, you can use a suppression ability that slows the zombies down, but I do just fine standing behind a low wall and firing my weapon. The issue is that the game has unsuccessfully merged the elements of ARPG and strategy. To throw a grenade, you must press five buttons. In an already bland action experience, you are slowing down the gameplay with poorly implemented strategy components. It honestly feels like two different games. One could argue that the game allows you to play the way you want, action oriented or strategy oriented, but neither side compliments each other. It is just a mess of ideas that do not seem to be completed or fleshed out.

What about those RPG features? Well, in this post-apocalyptic zombie world you kill enemies for currency and find items in crates. In addition to swapping out squad mate classes, you are able to choose their appearances from a list of premade heads. There are 6 classes in the game, all of which have the most uninspired skill trees I have ever seen. Great skills such as, “increase health”, “increase weapon damage” and “increase critical hit chance”. These passive skills greatly outweigh the active ones. I will admit, each class does have two or three unique active abilities, but as I said, they not very interesting. The item drops are as expected from a modern military shooter. Enemies drop “scrap”, which can be used to upgrade these items at work benches found at safe houses. As far as I can tell, scrap is the only currency in the game and it used to do everything at the work bench.

As one might be able to tell, this game did not gift me with the most enjoyable of experiences. Overall, it is a bland and uninspired mess of ideas. The game is now a year and a half past its initial release date and it still feels incomplete. The obvious bugs and presentation are not worth mentioning. They are just there. I do not recommend this $20 purchase. There are thousands of games on the market and they cost less and play better.

TL;DR

Did I like this game? No. Would you like this game? Probably not. Should you buy it? I would not recommend it.

reviewText:
This is an enjoyable little hybrid tactical squad / horde shooter game. In the wake of a zombie infection you control a four man military team against masses of zombies and other survivors trying to achieve your mission. You can do this by issuing orders to you team and micromanaging their every move or taking control of one and having the rest follow. You can swap between these seamlessly as the situation dictates and this system works nicely in the game, allowing it to keep a good pace. The game includes a character levelling system, varied equipment, and a difficulty that scales nicely as the game progresses.

I enjoy playing this game. I enjoy playing this game A LOT.

But it is painfully bugged, and feels unfinished. There are parts of it that are poliished to perfection and I get the feeling these were the parts that the Developers found interesting and enjoyed working on. The rest is in need of a lot of work.

Positives:
A well thought out character and equipment levelling system.
A nicely realised World environment, with the city in ruins.
'Dungeons' for when you don't feel like following a story, and just want a blast.
Achievements that are fair and feel rewarding to accomplish.Negatives:
The bugs and glitches. There are plenty...
The story feels disjointed and needs cleaning up. It loses track easily, and you often feel like you missed something.
Lots of uneccessary 'filler' in the game. A cover system where 99% of your enemies use melee, for example.Conclusion:

I really feel like this is a missed opportunity for a great game. It needs a lot of work to make this happen, but it is well within the realms of possibility. It is receiving regular updates, and I hope these will help polish out these problems, but until then I cannot recommend this game, even though I really want to. When this happens, I will gladly change to a thumbs up.

Pressing SPACE will let you go into tactical mode. You can easier cordinate your attack with all characters invidually. Zombies is a blast to kill and there are alot of variations of them as well. Gfx of the zombies are well made.

Graphics:

-The city is still very unfinished

Summary:
Do I suggest you buying this game? Yes, it fills a very niche roll and buying it now will not have you pay the full game price when it does fully release. Does it mean you should play it in this Alpha build? Answer is two-fold.

1. As a casual gamer, no.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While departing from the turn based strategy style gameplay of the original Breach & Clear Mighty Rabbit Studios has managed to not only improve upon their original title but to also breath new life into the tactical shooter genera. Ok so its not your typical tactical shooter in the sense that is not another FPS trying to  fill in the gap left by the original Rainbow Six that was released in 1998 but Breach & Clear: Deadline might be the first title I would consider as being a worth successor to the crown.

Unlike most modern day tactical shooters employ the standard issue run and gun gameplay we could expect from any FPS on the market with the added benefit of being able to target enemies or issue orders to other members of your team. This doesn’t make a tactical shooter. Breach & Clear: Deadline attempts to recapture the tactical control feeling (which is a staple of the genera) that has been missing from other games. It does this by allowing the player to not only issue orders to units like the standard go there and shoot that options you would expect, in Breach & Clear: Deadline the player is able to  issue move commands, move units behind cover, highlight targets, assign arcs of fire, all while gameplay is frozen eliminating the cumbersome feeling of fiddling with controls on the fly. This doesn’t mean you can't just try and run-n-gun your way through the game because that’s also an option, it just wont get you very far.

Along side the tactical shooter elements of the game there is also a good bit of a nostalgia due to the open world RPG style gameplay of the original Fallout series that will have you completing quests and looking for gear all while leveling up your squad and selecting different skills from the skill tree to upgrade each character and make your squad fit your play style.

Now don't get me wrong Breach & Clear: Deadline isn’t perfect and it's still in development, but so far it has shown to be the model of what an Early Access title should be. First off I think pitting the player against zombies is a little dated at this point and the over all story could use some work. Luckily the developers are actively improving the game based on user comments and bug reports, patches come out to fix major issues fairly promptly, and their very responsive and appreciative of the online community.

reviewText:
Breach and Clear: Deadline is okay, I guess? I know it is probably for other people than me. I haven't played the original, but I heard that that game is completely different (more tactical, more Rainbow Six-y), so I'm more than certain that you won't need to play Breach and Clear for this game. Unless you are the kind of unimaginative slob that absolutely needs to know the thrilling backstory of Spec Ops Shooty Bro #1 and Shooty Shoot Headshot Bro #3.

It's an action-RPG with elements of tactical breaching and clearing on it, but the actual strategy gameplay is weirdly tacked onto the act of running around the city with your Shooty Shoot Bros, shooting all the zombies and picking up all the gun attachments you can find. It plays like World of Warcraft: You see a civilian with an exclamation point over their head, you ask them why they have a piece of punctuation attached to their head, the civilian says 'a zombie put it there, a grammar zombie', then you go out with your squad and deliver a bullet lesson to the grammar zombie's forehead, then you get paid in punctuation. Sorry, where were we? Oh yeah, video games.

It has a very Left 4 Dead feel to it, being that there's a ton of cannon fodder for you and your team to steamroll. There's even specials that require more bullets to kill! Occasionally, you'll have to stop and plan out how you're going to get through this next group of zombies in a gated area, and occasionally it harkens back to its Breach and Clear namesake by having you fight other living humans with guns. You can skip these parts with grenades or, more hilariously, with signal flares that tell zombies where the lunch is at.

So the bad news is: I think the game is doing half-measures. Half-measures in its open world, half-measures in its storytelling, and really doing half-measures with its interface. It's more of a Diablo open world than a Fallout open world, and that's fine. But the interface makes me think bad things. The skill tree feels geared towards a more different game than the one being played. There's only options to switch between a primary and a pistol secondary, and ammo drops give types of rounds in clumps of three hundred, so only one member of your squad gets to shoot their tricked out shotgun with almost infinite ammunition while your automatic rifle wielding buddies don't get much and only get to fire their dinky pistols in Eat Shitville. This makes tactical encounters really fun!

Breach and Clear: Deadline is not a game I had fun with, but that's because I want more meat out of my roleplaying games beyond slaughtering and mayhem (or at the very least, stellar gunplay). Action RPG dudes or gun♥♥♥♥ers will want to give this a shot, though.

reviewText:
B&C Deadline is an interesting port of B&C into a zombie story, with both real-time and precise tactical moves, as well as a detailed RPG system and some limite crafting and outfitting. Add this to a zombie landscape where you help survivors fight your way through both zeds and human renegades, in a semi-free-form encounter-based campaign, and you have one heck of a game, if a bit hard.

The original B&C is purely counter-terrorism... You need to move a 4-men section of CT specialists through various levels in a turn-based mode where they will determine for themselves who to shoot at and when. Your job is to get them there by flanking. In B&C deadline, the zeds don't shoot back, but the renegades will. The problem is there's usually a lot more zeds and some of them can be quite nasty.

The prologue, which also serves as tutorial, teaches you the basics like movement, facing, first-aid, suppression, and so on.  Now, the system was changed to be pausable real-time. Hit pause to issue orders like move, use special ability, and so on. Or you can move in real-time. The trick of course, is there's almost no cover in real-time so it's only suitable if you run into a handful of zeds.

Periodically you run into larger herds, and they will rush you. The trick is find enough cover and have your team sufficiently spread out to provide overlapping fields of fire. Flanking shots do a lot more damage than frontal shots. The nasty part is the Zeds can come from all directions, and forgetting to pay attention and move to better cover can be lethal.

You start having been shot down over a major metro area, and your squad was all that made it. You run around the map for supply crates and bonus crates with special equipment, from armor to gun enhancements, from night viz to first aid kits. English:

Breach & Clear: Deadline is a game quite successful due to the mix of strategy and action, to the variety of locations and enemies, to the many quests and growth system of the soldiers and modification of weapons and equipments. Without some rare bugs, a calibrated difficulty and a mix more strategic and less hack 'n' slash, we would have been facing a little gem that is still interesting and exciting. reviewText:
NOTICE: This game since release in a few days went from almost all positive reviews to now having a 'Mixed' reviews rating. A rating dropping like a rock within a few days should be a warning to both customers and the devs, this game doesn't measure up. These negative scores will get worse as more people who are not absolutly in love with the game play it. I suggest a wait and see if this grabbed your interest at some point.

I loved the first B&C game. Not sure what happened here, I know they switched engines. But sticking to the old gameplay would have been a better decision. If they took the first game and added zombies and larger maps to that we would have had something. Here we have a clunky UI that is really not good at all. Camera is also sub-par. Hard to describe almost, the UI just never does what you want it to and fights you all the time. Like you click a soldier for an order, r-click, it stays in that r-clicked menu even after issuing an order. I don't see an order to reload. Stuff just acts weird, the UI just fights you too much and it's frustrating. The gameplay also seems to behave somewhat oddly.

Add on skills/specialities that seem to be no good vs a few that are good and an overall lack of incentive to keep playing mixed with broken online play you have a game that seems to have come out too early. Unless they massively overhaul the UI and change several core aspects of gameplay to improve them I don't think this game would be worth getting. I expected so much more after the first Breach and Clear, I can understand trying to be innovative but going backwards in many ways is not actual innovation. The devs appear to want to fix it, time will tell how things go. Other games had rough release from Early Access and smoothed over their issues with time, but I thought the point of Early Access was to get those issues before release not after. Regardless things are likely going to get better. If at a later point this game has it's issues ironed out and most common complaints that I agree with are resolved I will likely re-buy it. For now it's a sad 'not recommend' and I will update this review as necessary.

reviewText:
While I'm not of fan of these types of games, I'll admit that I enjoyed my time playing Breach & Clear: Deadline. I like the overall design of the tactical system. It's very dynamic and flexible, so it's easy to make quick decisions. It also has a nice level of depth to it; plenty of options for approaching different situations. That being said, there is a lot of stuff that gets presented to the player really quickly. For new players, such as myself, it's better to ease them into the mechanics of the game.
Building off of this, the game does come with a pretty nice tutorial. The prologue of the game introduces the player to the essentials of the tactical system without going into a lot of unnecessary detail. There's even a part that allows the player to freely test their new knowledge. But afterwards in the next level, you're given free reign of the tactical system, and there's a lot that doesn't get covered in the prologue. I felt the game could have benefitted from an informative section that explained some of the deeper mechanics if the player got confused about the UI or simply forgot what was explained to them in the prologue.
Moving on, I also liked the level of customization provided – from adjusting player abilities to changing the names of the guns. It makes the game more personal to the player; it feels tailored to their experience.
My main gripe about this game is its attention to dialogue – of which there is very little. Any dialogue comes in the form of the affirmative quips of the squad members as they perform different actions. None of the characters speak, not even the NPCs. It doesn't feel quite right in a game like this – where there's a lot of supposed communication – to have no dialogue between the characters.
Other than that – and what I stated earlier about informing new players – this is a solid game. The combat is engaging and interesting, and I'd like to see this level of polish put into more games.

reviewText: The combat interface is excellent and easy to navigate with both mouse and controller. It will only take a few minutes to understand how to properly play this game. There is a good amount of depth, with fully customizable units, different classes with their own skill trees. The combination of military tactics and zombie combat blend together really well. Things like using a mine you found and then using a flare to lure zombies right into it. If you are looking for a fun strategy game with a low learning curve and a good amount of depth, B&C: Deadline isn’t a bad choice.

reviewText:
I have always been a fan since its first release on Android, played the hell out of it on Kindle HDX, spent $12 of in-app coins, maxed Team out 3x on 3 devices.  This is a whole different twist, kind of Tactically played like Dragon Age Origins (with Pauses/planning), but in a Left 4 Dead world, without the T&A chicks.  Kind of a knockoff, but not as repetitive as L4D, single player.  Love the flares attracting hords, while tossing cocktail right into them, or laying down claymore mines for the Rushers trying to hit from behind.  My favorite Suppressing Fire is still effective, but eats up the limited ammo.
From what I'm hearing, it's not a full game.  I hardly noticed that, with less bugs than majority of games out there, still addictive to play!  The issues are the story is predictable, slightly dry, and NPCs don't have audio dialogue like the player's team already has a bit of, nor do they move or do anything on their own.  Not a whole lot of action other than shooting everything that moves, unlike original B&C that had Bomb Disarming, Terrorist hunt, and Escape modes that kept it fun.
Gameplay is still great, with sometimes being overwhelmed by zombies from behind, while being shot at by Mercs, and no where to run.  A lot of customizing perks tree is available when leveling up your team, but no individual stats.  Hopefully they add more to this incomplete game, but still well worth the dirt cheap price of this game!
Hope someday, Might Rabbit expands more than handful of staff members, and even has more online players/servers for Breach & Clear franchise.  The rate of leveling is very slow with bland story, so it would be great to use your team online more often, if more people played.

reviewText:
There’s a knack to creating the perfect combination; Mac & cheese, The Simpsons and Family Guy, Final Fantasy and Disney. All of the aforementioned combinations work as well with each other as they do on their own. However, it is quite possible to take two separately great ideas and merge them together into a product that, at its most basic level, simply does not work. Bringing me to Breach & Clear: Deadline – a combination that, on paper, makes perfect sense, but falls far short in practice.

A spin-off from 2013’s Breach & Clear, Deadline attempts to take the series in a bold new direction, unrestricted by cramped corridors and closed in spaces. This time around you take control of a group of four troops trapped within a decaying, zombie infested city, shut off from the rest of the world. You’ll have to track down survivors and aid them as best you can, whilst wiping out the undead scourge – all in the hopes of being exfiltrated by your army comrades outside the city.

The game opens in a laboratory, where you’ve been called in to investigate explosions and rescue any survivors, but it quickly becomes clear that there are unnatural forces at play. Vile creatures have taken over the laboratory, forcing you and your team to beat a hasty retreat. Once you have made it out into the open world, Breach & Clear: Deadline takes a sharp turn from tactical squad shooter, into squad-based action RPG territory. Now you are free to roam the map to look for people to save, missions to take on and zombies to kill.

In a further departure from the series’ roots, you can control each character individually, such as you would in a twin stick shooter. This new sense of freedom is at odds with the game’s tactical leanings, but proves to be a good fall back when your tactics have failed.

Early on in the game your squad finds a base camp set up by survivors, and from here you’ll be able to accept new missions, upgrade gear and craft new weapons. Missions are usually “fetch” in nature, where you’ll be asked to go out into the world to recover more supplies for the camp. The missions themselves are fine, if a little cliché, but its Breach & Clear: Deadline’s combat that truly leaves me scratching my head.

The game is absolutely at odds with itself. It tries to set a creepy, foreboding tone, meanwhile arming your squad to the teeth with an assortment of weapons, explosives and perks. Non-human enemies are usually slow and pose no real threat from a distance, meaning you can quite happily set your squad up in safe positions and let them plug away. When things get tough you can take direct control of a squad member and go to town on them with a shotgun or rifle, making light work of the enemy. There’s no real challenge to the combat. The game lazily tries to make up for this by sending wave after wave of enemies after you, but the high elasticity of your squad means you’ll usually be able to work your way out of a bind.


Admittedly Breach & Clear: Deadline is quite well put together, and on a technical level it ticks all the boxes that it needs to, to make a serviceable product, but its core concept just doesn't make any sense. Its two themes don't fit together well, making its action sequences feel long and drawn out.

I was never quite able to get over just how incongruous a combination Breach & Clear: Deadline is. It certainly isn’t a bad game, it just isn’t that much fun, and lacks the suspense that it tries so badly to evoke. If you’re not a fan of the series there’s no reason to buy this.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Reviewed with a copy provided by publisher. Review originally posted here: http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/08/breach-clear-deadline-is-dead-on-arrival/

reviewText:
Deadline plays in two major modes: an 'Action' mode which bears similiarities to twin-stick shooters - and a 'Tactical' mode (a pause, issue orders, then go system) which allows you to precisely positions your troopers and issue them commands. These commands include using special abilities, directing their fire and utilizing equipment such as grenades and medkits. You have four troopers in your squad recruited from various classes, each replete with their own special abilities (suppression, explosives, etc.) Your characters gain experience and level up from completing missions and slaying enemies such as zombies and mercenaries. They can then expend skill points to unlock new abilities. Characters can even 'cross-class' if they save up the skill points, allowing you to develop more versatile characters. Aside from some of the active abilities the passives include 5% increased chance to crit, 5% increased damage with a particular weapon category or 5% increased health. They aren't spectacular on their own but if you cross-class the right classes you can find some abilities and upgrades that properly complement each other.

Weapons, equipment and weapon modifications can be looted from crates and dead mercenaries. These weapons can also be modded provided they have the slots (up to 3). The weapon mods aren't terribly exciting though - they typically include items such as scopes, gas systems and triggers that either up the fire rate, improve accuracy or improve damage (while typically lowering accuracy). You can also spend scrap (in-game currency) to upgrade armor and weapons. However this just ups DPS or armor value by a set amount and the cost increases with each upgrade. Again, nothing too exciting there.

The zombies come in a few flavors include shamblers, runners, acid spitters and some big hulking brutes. If you get swarmed your characters will easily be cut down. Luckily if you have a medic you can revive on the spot. Barring that your dead teammates will rejoin you when you visit a safehouse. Safehouses include workbenches for modding and upgrading weapons as well as storage for excess items.

Mercenaries are distinguished by the weapons they wield - sniper rifles, assault rifles, shotguns, etc. They too can cut you down pretty quickly if you're exposed.

There are 'dungeons' of a sort in-game. Certain areas have multiple floors that you can explore for loot and experience. Each level of the dungeon has an exit that takes you back to the starting point regardless of how deep you've made it. In addition they are interspersed with safehouse-like floors that refill health and allow you access to a workbench and locker. I'm not sure how 'deep' these dungeons go (the furthest I could stomach was about 8 floors in the Jupiter Building). Each floor or level isn't particularly different from the previous ones in layout so you do feel like you're exploring the same layout over and over after a few floors.

Overall the game is enjoyable and fun, providing a mix of isometric-style shooting with some tactical direction. There is some character progression and development and while not as deep or exciting as I would like it works, especially with cross-classing. The missions and storyline have you backtracking quite a bit but the devs were kind enough to add in a fast-travel system so you aren't constantly walking back and forth.

TL;DR: Military dudes shoot zambies in action or tactical mode. Level up, find equipment, customize characters.


Post-release and patches edit: It seems that the developers have decided to throw in randomized zombie spawns during tactical gun battles with bandits, raiders, etc. While I could understand this as 'sound drawing the zombies to your location' the way it is currently handled is atrocious. I've had zombies spawn directly on top of my soldiers, directly behind with no warning. Previously zombies spawned outside of the combat zone and closed in on your location. Now they seem to spawn on top of you or behind you. This one change requires me to change my review to not recommended. This issue needs to be addressed for enjoyable, balanced gameplay.

In addition human enemies with firearms can easily sit behind cover and almost never be hit while your own soldiers - behind comparable cover - easily get shot over and over again. There's really no point in trying to do anything other than tossing explosives in these situations as even the slightest attempt at suppression and flanking will see your men shredded within seconds.

------Normally don't write reviews this long, if you want a summary go to the bottom.

One of the games I wish had a mixed button instead of yes or no
So I never played the orignal breach and clear, but let me be clear, I enjoy this game immensly despite its various flaws.

Before getting this game, watche lets plays, gameplay e.t.c.
This is a very niche based game. You will either enjoy it or you won't.

With that said lets jump in

Youre basically a squad of special forces trying to get stuff did.
You fight zombies, special zombies MUTANT ZOMBIES I DERSAY.
You command a squad of four people, there are five classes (6?) I believe. Each class has its own signature weapon, Assault Rifles, LMG's, Shotguns, Snipers and submachine guns.
Each class has roughly 3-5 active abilitites that let them do stuff.
A lot of times when dealing with enemies its pretty rock paper spock lizard demon, I.E there are multiple ways to deal with them. BUT that doesn't stop you from branching into other classes skill tree's or their weapons. Infact you can build your team however you want, Example: Four demolitionst with LMG's, suppression and medic skills.

There is real time that lets you run and gun and a tactical mode. Tactical mode lets you pause, issue orders, move your squad e.t.c Just a piece of advice, you can change it from holding down the key to keep it running to a toggle, just learned this five minutes ago.

In addition, while the storyline is somewhat linear, espically the begining, they have multiple procedural generated dungeons for funsies.

Also, if you do get this game, make sure to right click on the .exe in the steamfiles and make sure you are using your dedicated graphics card not your integrated. My biggest turn off was for a while I couldn't play this as it would run at 5fps, I know its horrible. I learned my Nividia card didn't always activate thanks to Mordheim, and now I sit at a steady 30-45, again not the best but its an improvement.


Overall I love this game, its quaint, its unique, its a specific niche game that I enjoy because its simplistic nature. I also love it cause not many games give you the real time/pause tactical squad based gameplay, Red Solstice single player being my other favorite of this genre.

Just to summarize, watch lets plays, know that this is a specific niche game, it is not for everyone, bugs and issues do exist, and a few can be personally fixed.
